templateDescription: When you want a name that stands out and will stand up over time.
templateOutcomes:
A portfolio of names that:

  • Stand out.
  • Cause people to think twice.
  • Invite a conversation.
  • You can grow into—not out of.

Avoid market-testing great names into mediocre names.

Align key decision makers to names with greatest potential.
templateObjectives:
Define the aspirations for your name.

Find fresh inspiration for your name.

Generate a portfolio of names that transcend the obvious and expected.

Bring your names to life to explore their potential.

Identify the biggest questions presented by your names.

Design experiments to help you learn the answers to your most important questions.

Accelerate selection and approval of new name.

templateDescription: When you want to speed up the learning process so that you can move your new way of doing things into the world more quickly—and achieve greater impact sooner.
templateOutcomes:
Be open: Share broadly across your team, organization, communities, industries, regions, and nations.

Be cooperative: Seek unexpected partnerships.

Be united: Integrate learning from across your portfolio small bets to build momentum and durabiltiy of difference making solutions.
templateObjectives: Admit you don't know, accept unknown futures, share insights, learning, and knowledge openly to accelerate progress.
templateThroughline: false

templateDescription: Use when you want to effectively review and improve the work efforts of your team.
templateOutcomes:
Alignment on tasks to be done.
New insights and ideas on how to manage and portfolios processes.
Honest feedback and improvements to current ways of working.

templateDescription: When you need to align what you do, how you do it, who does it, and when it gets done with why you do it—and the impact you want to have.
templateOutcomes:
Identification of the needs, opportunities, and tensions you hope to address.

A clear and compelling vision of the impact you might have.

A clear and compelling purpose statement.

Clear and compelling descriptions of the change you aspire to create.

Clear and compelling strategic imperatives.

Clear expression of the goals, results, and impact you hope to achieve.

Practical metrics to measure learning, progress, and impact.

Prioritized calendar of questions to be explored and milestones to measure progress.

Tactics for increasing probability of success and mitigating possibility of failure.
templateObjectives:
Define your aspirations and the impact you might have.

Find sources of inspiration that might help you elevate your game.

Let go of the orthodoxies, biases, and assumptions that might be holding you back from achieving more.

Generate a rich set of options for how you might accomplish your aspirations.

Quickly explore and evaluate those new options.

Identify and prioritize the big questions and small bets that might improve your strategy and execution.

Take advantage of the collective knowledge, experience, and insight of your colleagues, peers, outsiders, and beneficiaries.
templateThroughline: The Big Why, How, What, When, Where, and Who of what you will do—and the impact you might have.

templateDescription: When you need to align what you do, how you do it, who does it, and when it gets done with why you do it—and the impact you want to have.
templateOutcomes:
Identification of the needs, opportunities, and tensions you hope to address.

A clear and compelling vision of the impact you might have.

A clear and compelling purpose statement.

Clear expression of the values that will guide how you go about your work.

Clear and compelling descriptions of the change you aspire to create.

Clear and compelling strategic imperatives.

Clear expression of the goals, results, and impact you hope to achieve.

Options for operating and engagement models.

Practical metrics to measure learning, progress, and impact.

Prioritized calendar of questions to be explored and milestones to measure progress.

Tactics for increasing probability of success and mitigating possibility of failure.
templateObjectives:
Define your aspirations and the impact you might have.

Find sources of inspiration that might help you elevate your game.

Let go of the orthodoxies, biases, and assumptions that might be holding you back from achieving more.

Generate a rich set of options for how you might accomplish your aspirations.

Quickly explore and evaluate those new options.

Identify and prioritize the big questions and small bets that will help you better understand your challenge and the potential of emerging solutions.

Take advantage of the collected knowledge, experience, and insight of your colleagues, peers, outsiders, and beneficiaries.
templateThroughline: The Big Why, How, What, When, Where, and Who of what you will do—and the impact you might have.

templateDescription: Use when you want to explore principles that might guide your organization and shape your culture.
templateOutcomes:
Selection of potential values that resonate and guide

Prioritized set of questions about the implications and power of your values

Set of small bets to learn the answers to those questions and understand the true power of your values

Learning, rollout, and change milestones for your values
templateObjectives:
Articulate the difference you aspire to make in the world

Find fresh inspiration beyond your industry, sector, or geography

Overcome the biases, orthodoxies, and assumptions that limit who you are, what you do, and why you matter

Gain a richer understanding of how your values might manifest themselves in the real world

Discover the implications and power of your values

Accelerate time to impact for your values
templateThroughline: false

templateDescription:
• When you want to provide a framework to counter conventional problem solving approaches.
  • When you want to introduce someone to the six Think Wrong Practices. 
  • When you want to transition from one stage of a Think Wrong Blitz to the next.
templateOutcomes:
• Confidence in the process.
  • Ability to share and help others Think Wrong.
  • Understanding of which practices to use at critical moments.
templateObjectives:
• Counter conventional problem solving practices.
  • Provide practical guidance and framing for Think Wrong drills.
  • Increase comfort with Think Wrong’s unorthodox approaches and activities.
templateThroughline: The language, frameworks, tools, and techniques required to conquer the status quo and do work that matters.

templateDescription: Use when you want to help a group master Think Wrong language, frameworks, tools, and techniques.
templateOutcomes:
Think Wrong Master Class participants will:
  • Understand the Think Wrong problem-solving system—and when and how they might apply it
  • Be prepared to use the Think Wrong Frameworks to engage others in disruptive problem solving—while respecting the roles and value of those operating the way things are
  • Have working knowledge and access to the Think Wrong Lab as a platform and toolkit for disruptive problem solving
  • Have practical knowledge of how to design and apply Think Wrong Drills
  • Have practical experience designing, producing, facilitating, documenting, and reporting on Think Wrong Drills and Blitzes 
  • Identify one-to-many specific challenges to think wrong about followoing the Master Class
templateObjectives:
• Introduce Think Wrong language, frameworks, tools, and techniques
  • Learn Think Wrong language, frameworks, tools, and techniques through participant challenges
  • Prepare participants to immediately introduce and use the Think Wrong problem-solving system in their organizations, communities, industries, or sectors
templateThroughline:
A new problem-solving system that will help you conquer the status quo while inventing what is next.

  • Deflection point
  • Biology & Culture
  • Practice mismatch
  • Roles
  • Think Wrong Practices

templateDescription: When you want to make a meaningful difference, are willing to question the way things are, and eager to explore how things might ideally be.
templateOutcomes:
Be Courageous: Dare to imagine the biggest difference you could make.

Be Idealistic: Consider your legacy. What’s worthy of your life’s work?

Be Challenging: Refuse to accept the mandate of the status quo.
templateObjectives: Dare to imagine the biggest difference you could make.

templateDescription:
When you want to develop a compelling narrative for who you are, what you do, how you do it, and why it matters. 

When you want to change the way that you are understood by the people who matter most to your success.

When you want to align the expectations that you are creating and how you deliver against those expectations.

When you believe you are not realizing the full potential of your brand.
templateOutcomes:
Bold aspirations for your brand.

Compelling narratives describing who you are, what you do, how you do it, and why it matters.

Insights into what might need to change to keep your brand promise and achieve your brand aspirations.

Alignment among decision makers, leaders, and the people who are responsible for delivering your brand promise.

A portfolio of small bets and key questions to guide brand exploration, development, and delivery.

Prioritization of brand development activities.

Alignment of brand building activities to strategic imperatives.

Assignment of responsibility for key brand building activities to increase probability of success and mitigate risks.
templateObjectives:
Set the bar high for your brand and the impact it might have.

Identify a set of peers who can inspire and elevate your brand.

Escape the assumptions, biases, and orthodoxies that constrain your brand.

Imagine new possibilities for your brand.

Create compelling narratives for your brand.

Identify the biggest questions you have for your brand.

Design small experiments that will help you learn how to make the most of your brand.

Lean into the wisdom and experience of the people who matter most to build a brand that is authentic and matters.
templateThroughline:
How do we want to be understood by the people who matter most to us—and who we matter most to.

The expectations that we might create to lay the foundation for that understanding—and how we might show up at moments that matter to earn and strengthen that understanding.

How might we show up for the people we matter to most, in ways that build and strengthen how we are understood by them, so that we have long and fruitful relationships with them—and so that that they become our best advocates?

templateDescription: When you want to craft a vision statement for your organization.
templateOutcomes:
Inspirational ideas, goals, framing, and expressions

Agreement and alignment with most compelling elements

Draft vision statements
templateObjectives: Generate ideas, frameworks, and language that can help you describe your vision of the future—and the role your organization might play in shaping it.

templateDescription:
Use one or more of these drills to develop hypotheses about your customers’ most significant pains.

Tips: Focus on developing deeper insights into your key constituents' needs so that your solutions will be relevant and valuable to the people upon whom your success depends. 

Use the Customer Canvas Drill to collect output and insights from other customer-centered drills. Useful drills are identified on the Customer Canvas Poster.
templateOutcomes:
• Customer pains identified
  • Customer pains ranked
  • Market opportunities identified
templateObjectives: Develop hyotheses about which customer pains represent your biggest opportunities.
templateThroughline: Focus on developing deeper insights into your customers’ pains so that your solutions will be relevant and valuable to them.

templateDescription: Use one or more of these drills to kick start meetings designed to explore how you and your talent might get more from their full potential.
templateName: Kick Start Meetings with Your Talent—Set
templateOutcomes:
• Insight into growth opportunities
  • Insight into existing strengths for individual members of your team
  • Insight into what success and failure might look like
  • Strategies for increasing probability of success, and for reducing risk of failure
templateObjectives: Gain insight into opportunities for greater growth and contribution.
templateThroughline: Tip: Some of these drills are designed to be completed by teams for your organization, modify your instructions so that they can be used individuals in your organization to explore what inspires them and to develop new opportunities for growth and contribution.

templateDescription: Use one or more of these drills to identify and empathize with the key constituents (stakeholders) in society.
templateName: Identify Key Constituents and Their Needs—Set
templateOutcomes:
• Key constituents identified
  • Hypotheses for constituent pain and opportunity identified
  • Constituent “from/to” shifts developed

Tip: Change at the societal level requires that as many constituents as possible be considered and engaged in the process. Be clear about who matters most to your success—and why you might matter to them.
templateObjectives: Understand the many stakeholders in your society and what motivating, or demotivating, them to be a part of your effort.
templateThroughline: Change at the societal level requires that as many constituents as possible be considered and engaged in the process. Be clear about who matters most to your success—and why you might matter to them.

templateDescription: First Collider
When you want to get agreement on the most compelling challenge to blitz.
templateOutcomes:
A clear and compelling challenge statement

A starting place for exploration, experimentation, and discovery

Greater insight into opportunities for change and impact
templateObjectives:
Find a problem worthy of time and effort.

Set the bar high for the solutions you might create.

Stretch beyond the assumptions, biases, and orthodoxies that define the status quo.

Lean into the experience, knowledge, insight, and wisdom of your peers and outsiders.

Explore unaddressed pain points and opportunities for value creation.

templateDescription:
Use one or more of these drills to build greater empathy for your key constituents

Tips: Develop robust hypotheses about your key constiuents that can be tested through small bets and incubation efforts as you begin to develop your solutions.

Use the Customer Canvas Drill to collect output and insights from other customer-centered drills. Useful drills are identified on the Customer Canvas Poster.
templateOutcomes:
• Constituent personas to help keep your efforts “user centered”
  • Constituent insights to inspire solutions
  • Constituent hypotheses for testing
templateObjectives: Bring your key constiuents to life, so that you can keep them front of mind as you articulate problems, opportunities, and potential solutions.
templateThroughline: Develop robust hypotheses about your key constiuents that can be tested through small bets and incubation efforts as you begin to develop your solutions.

templateDescription: When you want to scale solutions across multiple cities.
When you want to scale solutions across multiple cities.
templateThroughline: false

templateDescription: When you want to get agreement on the most compelling new business opportunity to Blitz.
templateOutcomes:
Set the bar high for the new business you might create.

Stretch beyond the assumptions, biases, and orthodoxies that define the status quo.

Lean into the experience, knowledge, insight, and wisdom of your peers and outsiders.
templateObjectives:
A compelling new business challenge statement.

Focus for the kinds of insiders and outsiders to recruit for the Blitz.

Focus for the design of the Blitz.

Focus for the Incubation Team to form prior to the Blitz.

Focus on potential mothership management challenges.

Identify key influencers, potential obstructors, and decision makers.
templateThroughline: false

templateDescription: When you want to explore your personal growth challenge and create a portfolio of possible leadership solutions.
templateOutcomes:
• A portfolio of business hypotheses
  • Inventory of compelling desirability, feasibility, and viability questions
  • Development priorities
  • Incubation milestones
  • Initial business, product, and service scenarios
templateObjectives:
• Frame the opportunity and impact your new business might have
  • Find fresh inspiration for your new business
  • Escape the constraints of existing businesses and expand what is possible
  • Explore unmet market needs and potential solutions
  • Quickly learn what works and what does not
  • Accelerate speed to incubation and market
templateThroughline: Leadership language, frameworks, tools, and techniques that might apply.

templateDescription: When you want to shift from high-level abstract thinking and debate to more concrete and promising solutions.
templateOutcomes:
Be collaborative: Find co-conspirators who have something unique to offer—including the people you are building for.

Be ingenious: Make clever, practical, and original use of existing resources when building your solution.

Be simple: Build just enough to answer your biggest questions—avoid over building too early and be willing to share many shitty first drafts.
templateObjectives: Build with others to discover, understand, inspire further creativity, and inform strategy.
templateThroughline: false

templateDescription: When you need to identify who might matter most to you—and what you might do that will matter most to them.
templateObjectives:
• Identify potential customers
  • Identify customer pains
  • Identify market opportunities
templateThroughline: Customer pain

templateDescription: Use a combination of these drills when you are exploring how to express your organization’s mission.
templateOutcomes:
• A clear reason for existing
  • Alignment of intention and actions
  • Buy-in, commitment, passion, and engagement of your people, partners, and communities
templateObjectives:
Create a unifying statement that can:

  • Make your mission clear
  • Guide your actions
  • Reveal a path to impact
  • Guide decision-making
templateThroughline: Are you clarifying why you exist—the purpose that gets you out of bed in the morning/the mission that motivates and inspires you through good times and bad?

templateDescription: Use a combination of these drills when you want to define the belief system that guides your conduct and decision making.
templateOutcomes:
Clarity about the beliefs and “golden rules” that might govern you

Alignment with the values that are most important

Candidate value statements for consideration and adoption
templateObjectives: Articulate a belief system that captures the guiding principles that are most important to you.
templateThroughline: Values are your "Big How." They define how you conduct yourself with your colleagues and the rest of the world. Values are guided by beliefs and principles that you hold dear. Values do not need to be fact based. But they do need to reflect what is sacrosanct to you and your organization.

templateDescription: Use a combination of these drills when you want to gain clarity about the most duanting challenges and most promising opportunities ahead of you, where you might start, and what you might do after that.
templateOutcomes:
• Prioritized portfolio of ideas, small bets, and work effort
  • Categorization of transformative, incremental, and tablestakes ideas, solutions, and work effort
  • Insight into the potential of ideas, emerging solutions, and work effort to contribute to strategic objectives and desired impact
templateObjectives: To gain clarifty about what your top priorities might be.
templateThroughline: Focus on emerging solutions, small bets, and work effort that align with your strategic objectives and have the greatest potential for impact.

templateDescription: When you want to engage your Board of Trustees more deeply in the strategic work of your organization.
templateOutcomes:
Shared aspirations and audacious goals

Fresh inspiration for Board engagement and contribution

A portfolio of potential engagement solutions (experiences, processes, policies, tools, etc.)

A collection of small bets designed to produce rapid learning, insight, and fresh discoveries

Milestones, priorities, responsibilities, and assignments
templateObjectives:
Discover the aspirations you share with your Board

Find fresh inspiration for Board engagement

Let go of the assumptions, biases, and orthodoxies that are limiting your Board engagement and contribution

Gain insight into how your Board might engage and contribute to your shared aspirations

Discover what works, what might be improved, and what to avoid

Accelerate contribution and time to impact

templateDescription: When demoing the Think Wrong Lab
templateOutcomes: Awe
templateObjectives: Illustrate functionality and drill content

templateDescription: When you are deciding why and where to invest your time and resources.
templateOutcomes:
Be curious: Let discovery drive your solution.

Be experimental: Test your hypotheses and treat unexpected results as new opportunities for breakthrough solutions.

Be thrifty: Use the least amount of time and fewest resources possible to get answers to your most important questions.
templateObjectives: Manage portfolio of possibilities designed to produce LFI (Learning From Investment).

templateDescription: Use a combination of these drills to explore the aspirations and objectives for your strategy.
templateName: Explore and Define Your Strategic Objectives—Set
templateOutcomes:
Vision of opportunity for impact

Alignment with a set of shared objectives

Milestones for progress on your strategic objectives

Language for communicating your strategic objectives

false

templateDescription: When you want to help people identify the pains they are experiencing and the impact of those—so that they can begin to find solutions to them.
templateOutcomes:
• Picture of the current state and aspirational future state
  • Prioritized pains and jobs to be done
  • Insights into the consequences of those pains and the jobs not getting done
  • Solution map and insight into which are resonating with your prospect
  • Needs prioritized by willingness to spend/invest in solutions
templateObjectives:
• Demonstrate that you are prepared and interested in your prospect and their organization
  • Gain insight into your prospects goals and aspirations
  • Understand the pains, consequences, and jobs to be done that are most challenging to your prospect
  • Gain insight into what’s standing in the way of getting those jobs to be done
  • Map solutions—your’s and other’s—to the clients jobs to be done
  • Gain insight into the jobs to be done that are your client’s highest priority

templateDescription:
When you need to create or refresh your product marketing—find the language and stories that resonate with those that matter most, from those that matter most. Quickly learn the to-be states and how to position your offering against them, understand customer pains, key moments and the jobs-to-be-done and build your marketing around the people who drive your success.

A series of drills that provides step-by-step instructions for your team to quickly drive your product marketing initiative forward.
templateOutcomes: A portfolio of key messages, language and stories.
templateObjectives: Messages that resonate, stories that inspire, and a deeper understanding of those that matter most to your success.
templateThroughline:
Don't get bogged down in jargon, features and functions—understand where your customers (and those that matter most to your success) are today, where they want to go, and tell them how you can help them get them there with compelling messages, stories, and language that resonates.

Use the Ultimate Discovery Call template for your 10x10x10, it’ll give you the greatest insight and understanding of the people who need to hear you, don't outsource or trust others with this key task!

templateDescription: When you are seeking input for a new, or next, product release Product Managers often convene Customer Advisory Boards, these may be tagged on to the end of a conference, be part of a road-trip, be a conference call, or a online survey. Too often these are somewhat useless resulting in an uninspiring-incremental-meh of a release, or used as a way to reaffirm an annoited "product roadmap"
When you want to 2-3 drills to increase the number of product ideas available for further exploration, development, and consideration.
templateOutcomes:
Be uncensored: Turn off your internal judge and let your ideas flow unfettered by what might be right or wrong.

Be crazy: Imagine the nuttiest, wildest, most outrageous solutions you can.

Be prolific: Put quantity before quality.
templateObjectives: Trick your brain into a creative hyper-drive where unusual and surprising ideas emerge.
templateThroughline: Ignore that voice in your head trying to shut you down—let go and have fun generating as many ideas and possibilties as you can. Don't worry about evaluating, your will have time to do that later.

templateDescription: Use one or more of these drills to surface shared aspirations for your vision.
templateOutcomes:
Compelling language

Shared vision of the future 

Shared aspirations for impact

Compelling language and expressions of your vision
templateObjectives:
Identify what inspires and motivates everyone.

Align your team around a shared legacy and opportunity for impact.
templateThroughline: Identify what inspires and motivates you—what is your opportunity to make a difference

templateDescription:
Use one or more of these drills when you want to prioritize your goals for the next year.

Tips: 

Be realistic about the work effort required to make progress on goals. The agile development model depends on flexibilty and the ability to quickly adjust based on newly gained insights. 

Create timelines to guide efforts, not to restrict them or force them down paths that are inconsistent with what you are learning as you go.
templateOutcomes:
• Insight into priority activities
  • Insight into dependencies
  • Clarify around responsibilities
  • Insight into total scope of work
  • Milestones for agile development efforts

Tips: Be realistic about the work effort required to make progress on goals. The agile development model depends on flexibilty and the ability to quickly adjust based on newly gained insights. Create timelines to guide efforts, not to restrict them or force them down paths that are inconsistent with what you are learning as you go.
templateObjectives: Map important milestones to guide your work effort over the next year.
templateThroughline: Be realistic about the work effort required to make progress on goals. The agile development model depends on flexibilty and the ability to quickly adjust based on newly gained insights. Create timelines to guide efforts, not to restrict them or force them down paths that are inconsistent with what you are learning as you go.

templateDescription: When you need to define why your organization exists.
templateOutcomes:
• Clarity of reason for existing
  • Alignment of intention and actions
  • Commitment, passion, and engagement of people, partners, and communities
templateObjectives:
Create a unifying force among leaders, people and partners that can:

  • Make your mission clear
  • Guide your actions
  • Reveal a path to impact
  • Guide decision-making
templateThroughline: Are we clarifying why we exist and do our objectives, strategy, and tactics align with our purpose?

templateDescription: When you want to rank competing solutions, small bets, or work efforts.
templateOutcomes:
Ranking of solutions, small bets, or work efforts relative to each other

Tip: To ensure useful ranking occurs, force participants to decide position one item before/after, above/below each other. Prohibit placing items in the same position. Make sure to have participants spend some time discussing and get aligned on the definition of the sorting dimensions (i.e., Discuss “What do we mean by impact?” before sorting for impact).
templateObjectives: Determine where effort and resources should be directed.
templateThroughline: To ensure useful ranking occurs, force participants to decide position one item before/after, above/below each other. Prohibit placing items in the same position. Make sure to have participants spend some time discussing and get aligned on the definition of the sorting dimensions (i.e., Discuss “What do we mean by impact?” before sorting for impact).

templateDescription: Use when you want to explore principles that might guide your organization and shape your culture.
templateOutcomes:
Selection of potential values that resonate and guide

Prioritized set of questions about the implications and power of your values

Set of small bets to learn the answers to those questions and understand the true power of your values

Learning, rollout, and change milestones for your values
templateObjectives:
Articulate the difference you aspire to make in the world

Find fresh inspiration beyond your industry, sector, or geography

Overcome the biases, orthodoxies, and assumptions that limit who you are, what you do, and why you matter

Gain a richer understanding of how your values might manifest themselves in the real world

Discover the implications and power of your values

Accelerate time to impact for your values
templateThroughline: Our Big How: Are we enhancing values that matter to us—the principles that guide what we will, what we will not do, and how we will go about it?

templateDescription: When you want to explore why what you do might matter now and to future generations.
templateOutcomes: Inspiration, guidance, and motivation for you, your teams, and everyone who matters to your success.
templateObjectives: Set the bar high for the impact you might have.
templateThroughline: Our Big Why: Are we enhancing and aligning with our envisioned future—the desired impact that guides our strategy, innovation, and execution?

templateThroughline: Convergence on ideas and emergent solutions with the greatest potential to achieve desired impact

templateDescription:
When you want to develop a compelling narrative for who you are, what you do, how you do it, and why it matters. 

When you want to change the way that you are understood by the people who matter most to your success.

When you want to align the expectations that you are creating and how you deliver against those expectations.

When you believe you are not realizing the full potential of your brand.
templateOutcomes:
Bold aspirations for your brand.

Compelling narratives describing who you are, what you do, how you do it, and why it matters.

Insights into what might need to change to keep your brand promise and achieve your brand aspirations.

Alignment among decision makers, leaders, and the people who are responsible for delivering your brand promise.

A portfolio of small bets and key questions to guide brand exploration, development, and delivery.

Prioritization of brand development activities.

Alignment of brand building activities to strategic imperatives.

Assignment of responsibility for key brand building activities to increase probability of success and mitigate risks.
templateObjectives:
Set the bar high for your brand and the impact it might have.

Identify a set of peers who can inspire and elevate your brand.

Escape the assumptions, biases, and orthodoxies that constrain your brand.

Imagine new possibilities for your brand.

Create compelling narratives for your brand.

Identify the biggest questions you have for your brand.

Design small experiments that will help you learn how to make the most of your brand.

Lean into the wisdom and experience of the people who matter most to build a brand that is authentic and matters.
templateThroughline: false

templateDescription: Use when you want to explore unexpected, paradigm breaking experiences.
templateOutcomes:
• Clear and compelling aspirations and vision for the experience you might create.
  • A clear picture of who the experience matters to and why.
  • A clear picture of the change required (from the predictable path to status-quo busting experiences)
  • New sources of inspiration.
  • A portfolio of possible experience solutions.
  • Visualizations, models, and prototypes of experience solutions.
  • Small bets and experiments to gain insight into what might work, what might not—and to discover opportunities for breakthrough solutions.
templateObjectives:
• Define the difference and impact you want to create.
  • Find fresh inspiration for new experiences.
  • Let go of the orthodoxies, biases, and assumptions that are reinforcing the status quo.
  • Understand your experience challenges and opportunities more deeply.
  • Discover what might transform your experiences.
  • Achieve impact sooner.

templateDescription:
When you are starting a project or making a sale, and need understanding and insight from those that matter most to its success, to define the true nature of the problem, and develop a portfolio of starting points for delivering satisfaction to their needs—whether that be developing new products or positioning the one you are selling.

This 30 minute Think Wrong workout will not only give you the insight you really want, but give someone that matters to your success a new set of useful tools, and insight about themselves, theirs wants, pains, blockers and assets.
templateOutcomes: Understand their status quo (as-is state), what are their pains, and what would their bold path look like (to-be state). You will gain insight on the transformation they want, what is holding them back, what might get them there, and discover the underlying reasons for their pain. And if you’re positioning a product you’ll learn language and stories that resonate.
templateObjectives: Open ended questions are hard to ask, harder to answer, and people fill in the "I want to be helpful, but don't know what to say" gap with magical thinking—it’s a fatal flaw in the traditional approach. Use these drills to prevent that from happening. A quick way to get to the changes that need to be made
templateThroughline: Whether you are looking to design a new offering, or selling an existing one understanding what the pains of prospects, customers and the larger network are will be key to a successful outcome. These drills offer an engaging way to quickly understand the desired step change that will ultimately help you design a better solution, or position your offering as a satisfaction to their jobs to be done.

templateDescription: When you need to align what you do, how you do it, who does it, and when it gets done with why you do it—and the impact you want to have.
templateName: Top 20 Think Wrong Drills for Strategy—Set
templateOutcomes:
Identification of the needs, opportunities, and tensions you hope to address.

A clear and compelling vision of the impact you might have.

A clear and compelling purpose statement.

Clear expression of the values that will guide how you go about your work.

Clear and compelling descriptions of the change you aspire to create.

Clear and compelling strategic imperatives.

Clear expression of the goals, results, and impact you hope to achieve.

Options for operating and engagement models.

Practical metrics to measure learning, progress, and impact.

Prioritized calendar of questions to be explored and milestones to measure progress.

Tactics for increasing probability of success and mitigating possibility of failure.
templateObjectives:
Define your aspirations and the impact you might have.

Find sources of inspiration that might help you elevate your game.

Let go of the orthodoxies, biases, and assumptions that might be holding you back from achieving more.

Generate a rich set of options for how you might accomplish your aspirations.

Quickly explore and evaluate those new options.

Identify and prioritize the big questions and small bets that might improve your strategy and execution.

Take advantage of the collective knowledge, experience, and insight of your colleagues, peers, outsiders, and beneficiaries.
templateThroughline: The Big Why, How, What, When, Where, and Who of what you will do—and the impact you might have.

templateDescription: Now That's What I Call Wrong Thinking - like the classic mixtape of top hits, these are the top twenty drills that wrong thinkers are using in 2018.
templateObjectives: Use them when you want to think wrong like a pro.
templateThroughline: People want to set the bar high, Be Bold drills dominate the top 20.

templateDescription: When you decide where your inspiration and guidance will come from—who and what will inform your decision making.
templateOutcomes:
Be adventurous: Find inspiration in new people, new places, and new experiences.

Be attentive: Pay close attention to what is going on—looking for, listening for, smelling, and feeling what’s new—collecting the most compelling things as fresh inspiration.

Be receptive: Accept every offer without judgement and with an eye toward expanding what might be possibile.
templateObjectives: Open the apeture in your mind. Prime yourself to take in new information and make surprising, serendipitous connections along the way.
templateThroughline: false

templateDescription: When you want to explore names that might stand out—and will stand up—over time.
templateOutcomes:
Names that:

  • Stand out.
  • Cause people to think twice.
  • Invite a conversation.
  • You can grow into—not out of.

Avoid think right market-testing that can turn great names into mediocre names.

Align key decision makers to names with greatest potential  (by turning them into co-authors).
templateObjectives:
Define the aspirations for your name.

Find fresh inspiration for your name.

Generate a portfolio of names that transcend the obvious and expected.

Bring your names to life to explore their potential.

Identify the biggest questions presented by your names.

Design experiments to help you learn the answers to your most important questions.

Accelerate selection and approval of new name.

templateDescription: When you want to get agreement on the most compelling challenge or opportunity to Blitz.

A compelling challenge statement.

Understanding of the kinds of insiders and outsiders to recruit for the Blitz.

Focus for the design of the Blitz.

Focus to identify the core team responsible for moving the Blitz outcomes forward.
templateObjectives:
Set the bar high for the challenge you might take on—and the impact you might have.

Stretch beyond the assumptions, biases, and orthodoxies that define the status quo.

Lean into the experience, knowledge, insight, and wisdom of your peers.
templateThroughline: Make sure Challenge Statements tie to customer/constituent pains and opportunities to remedy them.

templateDescription:
When you want to develop a compelling narrative for who you are, what you do, how you do it, and why it matters.

When you want to align the expectations that you are creating and how you deliver against those expectations.

templateThroughline:
How do we want to be understood by the people who matter most to us—and who we matter most to.

The expectations that we might create to lay the foundation for that understanding—and how we might show up at moments that matter to earn and strengthen that understanding.

How might we show up for the people we matter to most, in ways that build and strengthen how we are understood by them, so that we have long and fruitful relationships with them—and so that that they become our best advocates?
